mdk

Interface MDK

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    MDKImpl

    public interface MDK
    The MDK API consists of two interfaces: MDK and Session. The MDK interface holds globally scoped APIs and state associated with the microservice. The Session interface holds locally scoped APIs and state. A Session must be used sequentially. The MDK instance is responsible for communicating with foundational services like discovery and tracing. There will typically be one MDK instance for the entire process, and one instance of the Session object per thread/channel/request depending on how the MDK is integrated and used within the application framework of choice.

    • Field Detail

      • CONTEXT_HEADER

        static final java.lang.String CONTEXT_HEADER
        This header is used to propogate shared context for distributed traces.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • mdk_MDK_ref

        static final quark.reflect.Class mdk_MDK_ref

    • Method Detail

      • start

        void start()
        Start the MDK. An MDK instance will not communicate with foundational services unless it is started.

      • stop

        void stop()
        Stop the MDK. When the MDK stops unregisters any service endpoints from the discovery system. This should always be done prior to process exit in order to propogate node shutdowns in realtime rather than waiting for heartbeats to detect node departures.

      • register

        void register(java.lang.String service,
              java.lang.String version,
              java.lang.String address)
        Registers a service endpoint with the discovery system. This can be called at any point, however registered endpoints will not be advertised to the discovery system until the MDK is started.

      • session

        Session session()
        Creates a new Session. A Session created in this way will result in a new distributed trace. This should therefore be used primarily by edge services. Intermediary and foundational services should make use of join(encodedContext) in order to preserve distributed traces.

      • join

        Session join(java.lang.String encodedContext)
        Create a new Session and join it to a distributed trace.
